posts.cooked:
Team 2056 OP Robotics is proud to present our 2025 technical binder and CAD drawing package for our Reefscape robot: LIGHTNING! image 703×906 78.6 KB

image 703×906 78.6 KB

image 703×906 78.6 KB

OPR25-2056 Technical Binder OPR25-2056 CAD Drawing Package The drawing package includes all the revisions made throughout the year to parts and subsystems. (Designated by the suffix R1, R2, Etc)

Feel free to ask any specific questions you may have.

posts.name: Andrew Jahng
posts.cooked:
Such a great robot to watch…

Was there a particular reason for choosing this archetype?

posts.name: MartinSV 3544 Mentor
posts.cooked: The effort made on the drawings is amazing. Can’t imagine how many hours that could’ve taken. What an inspiration!

posts.name: Kelly
posts.cooked: I love how the drawing package is kind of the ultimate interpretation of not releasing exact cad, but allowing people to see ideas and techniques and how the robot is designed and works. It’s very cool.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: Could you provide some more detail/a better view of the wrist floating axle and jack screw setup? I understand the concept but couldn’t find a good image of your particular implementation.

posts.name: Justin Tervay
posts.cooked: What was the software sequence & logic for lining up and auto-scoring?

posts.name: MH
posts.cooked:
Stunning execution of this robot archetype. I’m blown away by the consistency of this robot and the ability to just put up so many points and even outscore entire alliances by itself. Love to watch you guys every year!

I do want to ask though: What was the process like of selecting this archetype from the start, and why this over other ones for you?

posts.name: Rocky
posts.cooked: Highly agree, I can even argue this drawing package give more detail than releasing full CAD, as for full CAD I miss lots of details especially in construction of mechanisms

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked:
I’m not on 2056, but we copied this setup for our 2023 shoulder arm.

Basically the carriage itself has an open slot where the arm axle mounts, and at the end of the slot you tap a hole into the end of the plate. A grub screw rides in this tapped hole and allows you to press against the bolts that hold in the arm axle. Since the axle is now “floating” it’s center to center can be adjusted to tension the arm.

We originally used tube nuts to mount the axle but quickly learned those aren’t designed for these types of loads so we eventually replaced them for turned plugs.

Here’s some pictures of our 2023 implementation:

posts.name: Tyler Holtzman
posts.cooked:
Great questions so far, keep them coming.  Our design lead, @Khalsa , will put together some answers after school.

For us to ensure the most accurate and up to date information, we ask if you are not a member of our team, that you not answer questions asked to us in our design binder thread.  We also ask that our documentation or CAD files not be rehosted elsewhere in the event that we need to make a revision or update.  Thanks!
